data.title: First-looks at Oklahoma-made films 'Killers of the Flower Moon,' 'Stillwater' and other news
data.meta_description: The photo shows Leonardo DiCaprio alongside Lily Gladstone in a scene from 'Killers of the Flower Moon' and Matt Damon in a crowd in 'Stillwater.'
data.text:
First-look photos released for 'Killers of the Flower Moon' and 'Stillwater'

Film fans are getting first-looks today at two major made-in-Oklahoma motion pictures.

The Osage News has the first look at Martin Scorsese's adaptation of "Killers of the Flower Moon," which is currently filming in Osage County. The photo depicts Native American actress Lily Gladstone (Blackfeet and Nez Perce) as Mollie Burkhart and Oscar-winning actor Leonardo DiCaprio, who is also one of the film's producers, as her duplicitous husband, Ernest Burkhart.

With a screenplay by Oscar winner Eric Roth ("Forrest Gump"), the Apple Studios film is an adaptation of David Grann's 2017 New York Times best-seller and National Book Award finalist “Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI." The film will chronicle the murders of Osage Nation citizens in 1920s Oklahoma, after the oil boom made them rich. The brutal killings became known as the "Reign of Terror" and the center of a major investigation by the then-fledgling FBI.

The first-look photo features Gladstone garbed much like historic photos of Mollie Burkhart, complete with the Pendleton blanket around her shoulders, her choker and jewelry and her hair loosely pulled back.

The Osage News' Shannon Shaw Duty notes that the scene takes place in the Osage community of Grayhorse in 1919 and is set early in the couple's relationship, with Mollie inviting Ernest for a meal that includes the traditional Osage dish grape dumplings served on beloved red Spode dishes.

The details are an encouraging sign that Scorsese and his team are making good on their promises to handle the real-life story with care and attention to detail. Currently under production, "Killers of the Flower Moon" is tentatively due out in 2022.

Entertainment Weekly offers today a set of first-look photos at another Oklahoma-made movie: "Stillwater," Academy Award-winning writer-director Tom McCarthy's new thriller. It stars Oscar winner Matt Damon as Bill Baker, an oil rig worker, or roughneck, from Stillwater, who travels to Marseille, France, to help exonerate his daughter, who has been arrested for a murder she says she didn't commit.

"Stillwater" was filmed on location in Oklahoma and Marseille, which producer Jonathan King said in 2019 was "dream of any filmmaker or producer when you're making a movie that's about real people in a real place is to make the movie there."

McCarthy tells EW the crime in question occurs when Bill's daughter, Allison (Oscar nominee Abigail Breslin), takes a year off from school at Oklahoma State University to study abroad in Marseille. While there, she meets a woman with whom she has a relationship, and the crime that occurs involves that woman.

"Matt and I started going (to Oklahoma) early on to get a taste of the place and the people and spending time with roughnecks, in particular," McCarthy tells EW. "They really opened up their lives to us, and their worlds and their families. They were incredibly instrumental in helping us shape the story."

Focus Features will release the Participant and DreamWorks Pictures project domestically in theaters on July 30.

'Twister' celebrating 25th anniversary, with special screening planned

Twenty-five years ago today, the blockbuster "Twister" debuted in theaters.

Although a few scenes were lensed in Iowa, the stormy action vehicle was largely filmed in several small towns across Oklahoma, from Fairfax and Ponca City to Maysville and Pauls Valley. Wakita, where a large swath of filming took place, is now home to the Twister Museum, which is planning a 25th anniversary party on May 15.

The 1996 film stars Helen Hunt, Bill Paxton, Cary Elwes, Jami Gertz and the late Philip Seymour Hoffman. It follows teams of rival storm chasers as tornadoes erupt across the Sooner State. The blockbuster wowed with its groundbreaking special effects, and it was nominated for Academy Awards for best visual effects and best sound.

Oklahoma City's Rodeo Cinema will offer a special 25th anniversary screening of "Twister" at 7 p.m. May 22. For tickets and information, go to https://www.rodeocinema.org.

Tower Theatre announces first shows without COVID-19 capacity limits

The Tower Theatre announced today plans for its first full-capacity shows since the March 2020 COVID-19 outbreak.

When it hasn't been shut down due to the pandemic, the popular Uptown 23rd venue has been operating at limited capacity to allow for safe social distancing.

Americana star Shakey Graves' Aug. 12 return booking and comedian Kyle Kinane's Oct. 13 stand-up appearance at the Tower Theatre both are planned as full capacity shows. Tickets to both go on sale at 10 a.m. Friday at https://towertheatreokc.com.

Managing partner Stephen Tyler said the hope is for all Tower Theatre shows starting in August to be full capacity, unless specifically stated for an event.

"We are on the road to full capacity shows again. We will play each show and date case by case and just know the configurations may be different so check the event descriptions! Get your vax on and come gather safely with us in August," Tyler wrote on Twitter.

"We have to accept that some tours may dictate restrictions," he added in a message to The Oklahoman. "Kind of an unknown."

Still, it's nice to see the Tower moving in a direction that is more like normal.

Food Network star Alton Brown bringing live show back to OKC

Food Network star Alton Brown will bring a new culinary variety show to Oklahoma City Nov. 7 for a stop at the Civic Center Music Hall.

Audiences can expect more comedy, more music, more highly unusual cooking demos and "more potentially dangerous sciencey stuff."

Tickets go on sale soon for the OKC stop on the "Alton Brown Live: Beyond the Eats" tour at https://www.okcbroadway.com/altonbrownlive.

Kara Luther-Chapman joins Guthrie's Pollard Theatre as executive director

GUTHRIE – The board of directors of The Pollard Theatre Company has announced the appointment of Kara Luther-Chapman as executive director.

Luther-Chapman is obtaining her MBA from Colorado State University with an emphasis in not-for-profit administration. Luther-Chapman comes to the Pollard Theatre with nearly 15 years of experience in administrative management and the performing arts industries in both performance and direction.

Luther-Chapman joins the Pollard's newly appointed Artistic Director Jared Blount, who succeeds W. Jerome Stevenson as artistic director.

"I am very excited to be partnering with my dear friend and collaborator, Kara Luther-Chapman, in this artistic endeavor. Her expertise and ingenuity will be paramount in furthering the vision for the Pollard Theatre," Blount said.

Luther-Chapman's professional expertise includes former owner and creative director of Forever After Parties and production management for NETworks Presentations LLC. In addition, Luther-Chapman has served in various non-profit administrative roles, including the Oklahoma Goodwill and St. Mary's Episcopal School.

In combination with a deep passion for promoting community-based arts programs, Luther-Chapman hopes to develop the historic organization's mission further.

"We have a unique moment to restore and reimagine our next chapter during these unusual circumstances. At the same time, we ensure that the Pollard Theatre will remain an integral part of the Oklahoma community," Luther-Chapman said in a statement. "I am eager to work alongside Jared. We will face challenges as we navigate forward, but together, I believe, we can accomplish great things."

Luther-Chapman fulfills this new role for the Pollard Theatre Company effective immediately. For more information, go to https://thepollard.org.

OKC Museum of Art to debut Fritz Scholder exhibit 'Beyond Stereotypes'

The new exhibition “Fritz Scholder: Beyond Stereotypes” opens May 15 at the Oklahoma City Museum of Art. The exhibition features 10 prints and one painting from Scholder’s revolutionary “Indian” series, illustrating Scholder’s radical imagery of modern-day Indigenous life.

The exhibition will be on view on the museum's second floor through Nov. 7.

“Through his paintings and prints, Scholder challenged the popular stereotypical depictions of Native Americans within the world of fine art,” said exhibition curator Catherine Shotick in a statement. “The stereotypical depictions, which often cast Indigenous subjects as uncivilized, tragic or a mere curiosity, helped justify the genocide, forced relocations and continued disenfranchisement of Indigenous peoples.”

Scholder was born in Minnesota in 1937, and by 1964 was teaching painting and art history at the Institute of American Indian Arts in Santa Fe, New Mexico. An enrolled member of the Luiseño tribe, Scholder influenced a generation of Native American students during his time in New Mexico.

After relocating to Santa Fe, Scholder said he saw one too many over-romanticized and generalized depictions of indigenous people “looking at the sunset” and decided someone should “paint the Indian from a different context.”

In 1970, he was invited to collaborate with the Tamarind Institute, where he created his first print portfolio, “Indians Forever.” He continued to work in lithography throughout his career, creating a distinct body of work through experimentations in line and color. He died in Scottsdale, Arizona in 2005.

The museum is currently operating with timed ticketing and is open 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday 10 a.m. and noon to 5 p.m. Sunday. For more information, go to www.okcmoa.com.

UCO closing Broadway Tonight series with 'Ain't Misbehavin''

EDMOND — The University of Central Oklahoma's Broadway Tonight series will close its 2020-21 season with a performance of the Broadway classic "Ain't Misbehavin,’” at 8 p.m. Thursday-Sunday at the UCO College of Fine Arts and Design House Courtyard, 320 E Hurd St.

The show is set during the Harlem Renaissance, and UCO students will portray Bessie Smith, Billie Holiday, Lena Horne and the Dandridge sisters as they shape an art form alongside men such as Thomas "Fats" Waller.

"The music is the star of the show," said Greg White, director of UCO's Musical Theatre division and executive director for Broadway Tonight, in a statement.

"It's a celebration of the music of Fats Waller, a prolific Black composer in mid-century America."

The event is supported, in part, by the Oklahoma Arts Council, which receives support from the state of Oklahoma and the National Endowment for the Arts.

Tickets are $35 and can be purchased by calling the Mitchell Theatre box office at 405-974-3375 or online at https://cfad.vbotickets.com/events.

-BAM
